","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Hanji-Attack-On-Titan-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn40@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-17-784_48230beeb943c3cf.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700503},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"REVIEW: Mega Man: Fully Charged #1 Revisits the World of the Animated Series","link":"https://www.cbr.com/mega-man-fully-charged-review/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mega-man-fully-charged-1-main-cover.jpg\"/></figure><p>Capcom's iconic video game franchise <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/mega-man/\"><em>Mega Man</em></a> received a new animated television series in 2018, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/mega-man-fully-charged/\"><em>Mega Man: Fully Charged</em></a>, running for an impressive 52 episodes. While the animated series may have to an end, it receives its own comic book adaptation from BOOM! Studios in a six-issue miniseries crafted by several of the writers behind the animated series, following the Blue Bomber, his father Doctor Light and sister Suna to defend humanity from nefarious Robot Masters that threaten their home of Silicon City. And while the first issue is a genuine thrill ride for fans of the video game character and the animated series, those unfamiliar with the franchise may want to look elsewhere for a jumping-on point to the video game.</p><p>As Doctor Thomas Light steps up as a negotiator and peacemaker between the robots and humanity, he quickly finds himself in over his head when a diplomatic mission goes wrong outside of Silicon City. As Mega Man leaps to his rescue, the young boy finds himself confronted with mysterious visions from his forgotten history that shakes him to his core. As Aki Light attempts to reconcile his strangely shattered memories, he finds himself on an adventure that could determine the fate of Silicon City as he sets out to rediscover his own identity.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mega-man-fully-charged-army-robots-first-look/\">Mega Man Battles an Army of Robots in Fully Charged First Look</a></span></p><p>Series writers A.J. Marchisello and Marcus Rinehart team up for the comic book adaptation, with series co-creator and executive producer Joe Kelly serving as a creative consultant for the miniseries. The writers continue to have a strong handle on each of the character's voices, transitioning seamlessly from animated television to the comic book medium, with Aki and Light each getting ample time to shine in the opening issue. Right from the opening, the comic is noticeably darker in tone than its animated source material, with Marchisello and Rinehart crafting a more action-packed take while Aki is much more serious than he had been on the animated series and it largely works as a continuation to the show.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mega-man-fully-charged-1-preview-1.jpg\"/></figure><p>This darker and hard-edged approach is evident with Stefano Simeone's artwork right from the jump. Joined by colorist Igor Monti, the visuals for the comic adaptation dials up its cyberpunk sensibilities while sequences taking place outside of Silicon City evoke a post-apocalyptic feel as Light and Mega Man navigate the wasteland. A major action sequence that serves as the centerpiece of the opening issue is definitely gripping, as Mega Man confidently charges into battle while his opponents feel like something out of Samurai Jack, robotic yet wholly menacing as they loom over Light and the Blue Bomber. Simeone's designs certainly feel like a continuation of the characters from the animated series, but there is more visible anime influence while Monti's choice in color palette plays up the shadow and light to ground the proceedings.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mega-man-treasure-trove-manga-fans/\">Mega Man Is a Treasure Trove for Manga Fans</a></span></p><p>For those looking for the next step in the ongoing saga of Mega Man as he and his father maintain the fragile peace between humanity and robots, BOOM! Studios' comic book adaptation is fun, more mature ride for fans of the animated series. While the more familiar antagonists and supporting characters from the wider franchise have yet to play a major role, the creative team wastes no time in establishing the world and tone of their approach to the long-running video game franchise. As for those that have no real background with the Blue Bomber's adventures or younger fans of the animated series, <em>Fully Charged</em> may not be the place to delve into Capcom's franchise.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mega-man-legends-action-adventure/\">Mega Man Legends Is the Outcast of the Game Franchise</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 20:20:49 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mega-man-fully-charged-1-main-cover.jpg","linkMd5":"9e09a5faa5c0864908243a93cbb75ae3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn29@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-00-770_5a94260a849f6b6d.webp","destWidth":1031,"destHeight":1734,"sourceBytes":220045,"destBytes":202488,"author":"Sam Stone","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mega-man-fully-charged-1-main-cover.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn29@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-00-770_5a94260a849f6b6d.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mega-man-fully-charged-1-preview-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn33@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-10-125_f04dee8a0f8d2f41.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700506},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Top 10 Spies In Marvel Comics | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/best-spies-marvel-comics-black-widow/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Top-10-Spies-In-Marvel-Comics-featured-image.jpg\"/></figure><p>If someone is part of a superhero team like the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/avengers/\">Avengers</a>, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/fantastic-four/\">Fantastic Four</a>, or <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/x-men/\">the X-Men</a>, keeping abreast of the clandestine actions of the Masters of Evil, Frightful Four, or Brotherhood of Evil Mutants would be foremost on their mind, and vice-versa.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-things-need-know-heart-of-universe-trivia/\">Marvel: 10 Things You Need To Know About The Heart Of The Universe</a></span></p><p>One way to do so, aside from sitting around HQ waiting for someone to launch an attack, is to send covert operatives into the enemy camp for some good, old-fashioned espionage. Luckily, whether hero or villain, the Marvel Universe is replete with agents who possess the requisite skills to excel in the spy game.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>SPYMASTER</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Spymaster.jpg' /></figure><p>With a name like Spymaster, he would have to be good at espionage. The moniker was adopted by three different supervillains, each one having a distinct and personal vendetta <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ranked-iron-man-villains/\">against Iron Man</a>. Each individual also had extensive expertise in the art of espionage, being skilled in covert operations, disguise, hand-to-hand combat, and weaponry.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/iron-man-marvel-comics-pathetic-villains-lamest-losers/\">Iron Man: His 10 Most Pathetic Villains</a></span></p><p>Each Spymaster has worked extensively for several nefarious underground criminal organizations and individuals such as A.I.M., Roxxon, The Maggia, and Justin Hammer. Despite any of the specific dictates of any of Spymaster's contracts, however, Iron Man always remains dead in his sights.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>MOON KNIGHT</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Moon-Knight-feature.jpg' /></figure><p>Marc Spector has worn many different hats in his life. He's been a boxer, CIA agent, mercenary, and is currently operating as a costumed <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-moon-knight-worst-deeds/\">vigilante known as Moon Knight</a>. As the living embodiment of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/avengers-who-is-khonshu-the-god-of-moon-knight/\">Egyptian God Khonshu</a>, Moon Knight fights crime in his name.</p><p>Interestingly, Spector himself suffers from Dissociative Identity Disorder, causing him to manifest several different personalities. One of them is a cab driver who spies on criminals and gains information on their activities. With his particular set of skills, Moon Knight is an effective agent of espionage.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>AGENT COULSON</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/agent-coulson.jpg' /></figure><p>Agent Phil Coulson made his debut through the MCU, but like many characters who appear in film or television media, he eventually <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/phil-coulson-his-15-best-moments-in-comics/\">found his way into the comic books</a>. As an agent of S.H.I.E.L.D. and one of its (eventual) high-ranking commanders, Coulson is brave, decisive, self-sacrificing, and savvy.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mcu-marvel-comics-shield-changes/\">10 Ways The MCU Changed S.H.I.E.L.D. In the Marvel Comics</a></span></p><p>Coulson's skills are more or less similar to other S.H.I.E.L.D. agents. He is proficient with various forms of weaponry and firearms, an expert in hand-to-hand combat, and has a sound tactical mind. These skills, coupled with his tremendous personal attributes, have allowed Coulson to work as an effective spy for years.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>THE FOREIGNER</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/The-Foreigner.jpg' /></figure><p>Modeled after a certain <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-comic-heroes-james-bond-win-lose-against/\">sly and debonair Hollywood super-spy</a>, the Foreigner is a handsome and extremely dangerous expert in the art of espionage. A master of disguise who's highly adept at the martial arts, the Foreigner was able to incapacitate the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/black-cat-5-dc-villains-she-would-team-up-with-5-shed-hate/\">Black Cat</a> with one blow, without her ever knowing he was there.</p><p>Part of the Foreigner's allure is actually based on a meta-human ability to temporarily hypnotize someone with his gaze. This explains not only his ability to get the drop on people but how he managed to marry Silver Sable for a time.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>MYSTIQUE</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Mystique.jpg' /></figure><p>Mystique’s proficiency at espionage is obviously aided by <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-mystique-powerful-mutants-impersonated/\">her shapeshifting ability</a>, but it is far from the only tool that makes her an effective spy. She’s a master at hand-to-hand combat, digital information technologies, weaponry, and commando military strategies. She also has a gift for acting, mimicry, and psychology, which makes her effectiveness in the field even more impressive.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-mystique-best-worst-mutant/\">X-Men: 5 Times Mystique Was The Best Mutant (&#38; 5 She Was The Worst)</a></span></p><p>There are multiple instances in the comics where Mystique's covert activities were instrumental to the Brotherhood’s ability to further their agenda, such as her assumption of an advanced position in the US government.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>JESSICA DREW</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Spider-Woman-Jessica-Drew.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-things-everyone-forgets-about-spider-woman-jessica-drew/\">Jessica Drew’</a>s fantastical powers as Spider-Woman may be what fans associate most with her, but she’s a pretty effective spy, to say the least. Firstly, she’s highly adept in the art of espionage, able to infiltrate any organization or situation with relative ease.</p><p>Secondly, Drew has been part of several of the Marvel Universe’s top espionage and counter-intelligence agencies, including S.H.I.E.L.D., the Secret Avengers, and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/secrets-hydra-marvel-fan/\">even HYDRA</a>. Lastly, she’s even managed to function as a double agent. Having joined HYDRA at the behest of Nick Fury, Drew was tasked to learn all she could about how their terrorist cells worked.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>THE SKRULLS</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/skrull-featured-1.jpg' /></figure><p>Maintaining a convincing and believable alias when undercover is one of the paramount objectives and concerns of a spy. In this regard, being a shapeshifter is beyond advantageous, and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/empyre-skrull-worst-moments-ranked/\">The Skrulls</a> are the Marvel Universe’s shapeshifters extraordinaire.</p><p>Able to not only assume the appearance of an individual but also their meta-human abilities, a Skrull well-versed in their target’s behavior and environment can successfully stay undercover for years. This was the case when the Human Torch discovered his wife Alicia Masters was actually a Skrull named Lyja, and when the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-secret-invasion-ways-timeless-vs-aged-poorly/\">entire <em>Secret Invasion</em></a> was revealed when Spider-Woman was uncovered as a Skrull.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>AGENT MARIA HILL</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/AGENT-MARIA-HILL-marvel.jpg' /></figure><p>Most people are familiar with Agent Maria Hill through her adept portrayal by Cobie Smulders in multiple MCU films. While the film version of Hill inspires a modicum of likeability and respect, the comic book version has been decidedly more ambiguously received.</p><p>Although Hill has worked assiduously as both an agent and the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-shield-best-directors-ranked/\">director of S.H.I.E.L.D.</a>, she sometimes makes questionable decisions. During <em>Civil War</em>, she sided with Iron Man and made it her mission to arrest Captain America – a dubious aim regardless of the circumstances. Unfortunately, due to Hill's effectiveness as a covert operative, her organization succeeded in bringing him in.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>BLACK WIDOW</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/black-widow-journey-into-my.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/black-widow-facts-trivia-marvel/\">Black Widow</a> is synonymous with espionage in the Marvel Universe. Natasha Romanoff was raised as a young girl to be the ultimate spy, proficient in hand-to-hand combat and weapons, disguise, infiltration, and a slew of other espionage-related talents.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/black-widow-best-cosplay-that-marvel-comics/\">10 Black Widow Cosplay That Look Just Like The Marvel Comics</a></span></p><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-black-widow-overrated-underrated-mcu-moments/\">Black Widow has served the Avengers</a> well over the years as one of their members and has proven useful to Iron Man as an ally. Moreover, she was romantically linked to Daredevil for a time, and her abilities as a fighter and spy definitely aided his war on crime.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>NICK FURY</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Nick-Fury-feature.jpg' /></figure><p>Bar none, Marvel's greatest spy is Nick Fury. Director of S.H.I.E.L.D. for what seems like an eternity, Fury's got his finger on the pulse of everything that happens in the Marvel Universe, whether its Magneto's latest move against humanity or Thanos' maneuverings in outer space.</p><p>Tough, brash, and well-versed in the spy game, Fury's \"secrets have secrets,\" as the MCU Tony Stark noted. Fury has been known to keep his cards very close to his vest, even amongst his allies. Whether it's the version that looks like <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/nick-fury-best-quotes-mcu-marvel-samuel-l-jackson/\">Samuel L. Jackson</a> or the one that looks like David Hasselhoff, Nick Fury is the pre-eminent spy in The House of Ideas.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-infinity-war-vs-infinity-gauntlet-better-story/\">Marvel: 5 Reasons Infinity War Is Better Than Infinity Gauntlet (&#38; 5 Why It Isn't)</a></span></p>\n +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Top-10-Spies-In-Marvel-Comics-featured-image.jpg","linkMd5":"e5086a6e59583aef84d178cda370848d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-00-601_f8ef6216cb3b6f50.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":171690,"destBytes":171690,"author":"Julian Beauvais","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Top-10-Spies-In-Marvel-Comics-featured-image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-00-601_f8ef6216cb3b6f50.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Spymaster.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn77@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-08-610_6d8634dadb16d3f8.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Moon-Knight-feature.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn93@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-11-299_a2cc14c2d924ff25.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/agent-coulson.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn26@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-13-390_bc1416879bedb4fa.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/The-Foreigner.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn46@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-05-957_ad50150606d96d64.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Mystique.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn6@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-09-002_91f7a2d9caad6721.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Spider-Woman-Jessica-Drew.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn74@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-08-026_a649cb1da11aa0d4.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/skrull-featured-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn17@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-12-434_b370a899a9c61720.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/AGENT-MARIA-HILL-marvel.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn13@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-14-061_70b71a417d7cd254.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/black-widow-journey-into-my.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn11@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-16-549_a45a29aef4743e00.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Nick-Fury-feature.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn43@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-05-916_7e5936fe53f6ae9f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700508},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"The Witcher 3: 10 Geralt Cosplay That We Absolutely Love | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/witcher-3-geralt-cosplay-best/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/The-Witcher-3-10-Geralt-Cosplay-That-We-Absolutely-Love-featured-image.jpg\"/></figure><p>It is unanimously agreed upon by the majority of the gaming community that <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-witcher-3/\"><em>The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt</em></a> is not only <a href=\"https://gamerant.com/open-world-video-games-best-past-decade-metacritic/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">one of the best open-world games ever</a> but one of the best games period. Beautiful visuals, intense yet fantastic gameplay and combat, well-written story missions that are unique in their own ways, and a plethora of other features make it a video game of legendary status that any gamer worth his two-cents is bound to enjoy.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-witcher-geralt-of-rivia-marvel-heroes-he-can-defeat-would-lose-to/\">The Witcher: 5 Marvel Heroes Geralt Can Defeat (&#38; 5 He Can't)</a></span></p><p>The franchise has proved famous enough to get a Netflix series of its own starring <em>Man of Steel</em> actor Henry Cavill. A big reason behind the popularity of the games is their solid, bad-ass, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/scariest-anime-monsters-of-all-time/\">fantasy monster-slaying</a> protagonist, Geralt of Rivia. He has grown into one of the most popular video game characters in recent times, and with that popularity comes a variety of cosplays featuring the character.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>A Dance Under The Trees</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/geralt-cosplay-image.jpg' /></figure><p>Cosplay by <a tabindex=\"0\" href=\"https://www.instagram.com/alexwolf_cosplay/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">alexwolf_cosplay</a>.</p><p>Witchers aren't really known for their first-rate dancing skills, but this cosplay featuring <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/witcher-3-characters-zodiac-signs/\">Geralt and Shani</a> does paint the picture of a lovely atmosphere. Yennefer of Vengerberg and Triss Merigold are the two main romance options open for Geralt in <em>The</em> <em>Witcher 3</em>, but there are many other women present in the games with whom the player can romance.</p><p>One of them is Shani, a medic who is missing from the main <em>The Witcher 3</em> game but can be found in the <em>Hearts of Stone </em>DLC.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>A Family Gathering</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>Yennefer is commonly accepted as the main love of Geralt's life, and Ciri is like their surrogate daughter. The three of them <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/strangest-marvel-relationships/\">don't exactly fit into the mold of a traditional family</a>, but they do care deeply about each other.</p><p>Triss is a close friend to them. While in the games the four of them never got together for Christmas dinner as shown in the cosplay, it is certainly interesting to imagine this rough and tough group of people in such a wholesome situation.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>An Armoured Warrior</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>The \"mutagens\" and experiments that were forced on to Geralt to morph him into a Witcher physically altered him in many ways, namely making his hair white permanently and giving him inhumane levels of stamina, speed, and strength. He can survive hits that would kill a normal human being, but is not invincible and thus <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/witcher-3-coolest-armor-sets-ranked/\">can be seen wearing armor at all times in the games</a>.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/witcher-3-vs-dark-souls-3-better-game/\">5 Things The Witcher 3 Does Better Than Dark Souls 3 (&#38; 5 Things Dark Souls 3 Does better)</a></span></p><p>Geralt's most iconic outfit is his chainmail armor, which can be clearly deduced to be the prime focus of this well-crafted cosplay.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>A Fearsome Trio</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>Geralt quite literally has the title of \"white wolf\" in his name. Even besides that, he has always been somewhat of a lone wolf, traveling the land of known and unknown regions <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/witcher-3-geralt-vs-video-game-monsters/\">hunting down monsters all by himself</a>.</p><p>Yet, every now and then Geralt finds himself in the company of others, be it by choice or not. The group of cosplayers featured in the picture look ready and willing to head into battle at any moment, which is indeed an appropriate look for Geralt and his fellow Witchers.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>A Hooded Figure</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>Two of the most important facial features of Geralt, and the most striking as well, are his eyes and battle scars. The scars are pretty self-explanatory, but the story behind his distinct <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/powerful-eye-abilities-anime/\">piercing eyes</a> is a tad bit longer. In the books, his eyes have never been specified to be of a color and are just mentioned to be \"dark.\"</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-witcher-dc-comics-geralt-heroes/\">The Witcher: 5 DC Heroes Geralt Can Defeat (&#38; 5 He Can't)</a></span></p><p>But in the games, they can be clearly seen to be dark amber and yellowish. This might have something to do with Geralt's \"Witcher Senses\" ability in the third game which allows him to view the world with superhuman senses.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Ready To Fight</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>The most striking part of this cosplay and the one that catches the eye first is the balanced amount of lighting. The engraving on the sword is clearly visible as well, which is a neat little feature that shows the cosplayer's exceptional dedication towards attention to detail.</p><p>In the games, Geralt's <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/best-sword-wielding-comic-book-heroes-ranked/\">swords aren't just pieces of metal</a> to defeat monsters, but they come with extensive histories of their own. The battle stance shows that Geralt is ready to run straight into his next fight.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>On The Hunt</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>Although Geralt might seem like a man of barbarian nature who always works in brutish ways, in reality, a vital part of the game involves using his superhuman senses to track down objects, people, or enemies.</p><p>Sure, Geralt's super strength and swordsmanship have kept him alive against all those deadly beasts, but his tracking skills are indispensable as well. All of these factors combine to make Geralt the legendary Witcher that he is.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>A Powerful Magic User</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>Digital alteration with software such as Photoshop can be a great way to include effects or highlights in a cosplay picture that would be impossible or difficult to do with practical effects. In this case, not only is the costume well done, but the cosplayer uses heavy editing to exhibit Geralt's magic powers.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-witcher-bosses-look-tougher-than-they-are/\">The Witcher Series: 10 Bosses That Look Way Tougher Than They Really Are</a></span></p><p>In the game, a big portion of the combat mechanics was dependent on the player's use of various spells, both defensive and offensive in nature.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Roach and His Rider</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>As open-world games keep getting bigger, traversing them is becoming a tougher chore. One way to combat this is for developers to give the player a travel companion, something almost all games are doing nowadays.</p><p>Geralt's horse Roach is as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-fan-favorite-animal-companions/\">loyal and trustworthy as a companion can get</a>, who will transcend the limits of space and time to teleport to the protagonist's location at a single summon. The two have faced a great many monsters together, and this full suited cosplayer on the back of his mare looks ready to do so as well.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Deep In Meditation</h2><figure><img src='' /></figure><p>Meditating is a very crucial feature present in all <em>The</em> <em>Witcher </em>games. It allows the player to restore Geralt's health and endurance, and it is also a good way to initiate a time-lapse (such as to go from day time to night time).</p><p>An even better in-universe explanation would be that it gives Geralt (and the player as well) a moment of peace and tranquility among all the war and fighting. This cosplay certainly sets a peaceful aesthetic befitting of a resting warrior tired from all the fights he has been in.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/netflix-witcher-fantasy-comic-books-similar/\">10 Fantasy Comics To Read If You Like Netflix's The Witcher</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 20:30:20 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/The-Witcher-3-10-Geralt-Cosplay-That-We-Absolutely-Love-featured-image.jpg","linkMd5":"414193a89842390df3b012673985bc0e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn61@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-01-950_c6315cd1020025b4.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":172072,"destBytes":172072,"author":"Mahir Wasif","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/The-Witcher-3-10-Geralt-Cosplay-That-We-Absolutely-Love-featured-image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn61@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-01-950_c6315cd1020025b4.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/geralt-cosplay-image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn52@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-17-055_d351c11a08d67678.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700506},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Jack Kirby's DC Debut 50 Years Ago Was Wild, Wonderful... and Worrying","link":"https://www.cbr.com/jack-kirby-dc-debut-jimmy-olsen-50th-anniversary/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-jack-kirby-debut-header.jpg\"/></figure><p>This is <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/look-back/\">\"Look Back,\"</a> a feature that I plan to do for at least all of 2019 and possibly beyond that (and possibly forget about in a week, who knows?). The concept is that every week (I'll probably be skipping the four fifth weeks in the year, but maybe not) of a month, I will spotlight a single issue of a comic book that came out in the past and talk about that issue (often in terms of a larger scale, like the series overall, etc.). Each week will be a look at a comic book from a different year that came out the same month X amount of years ago. The first week of the month looks at a book that came out this month ten years ago. The second week looks at a book that came out this month 25 years ago. The third week looks at a book that came out this month 50 years ago. The fourth week looks at a book that came out this month 75 years ago. The occasional fifth week looks at books from 20/30/40/60/70/80 years ago.</p><p>Today, we look at the August 1970 DC comic book debut of Jack Kirby, as he took over writer/penciler duties on Superman's Pal, Jimmy Olsen #133. </p><p>As you may or may not know, there are two special things about Jack Kiby's run on Superman's Pal, Jimmy Olsen. The first is that, well, why in the world was Jack Kirby starting his DC tenure on Superman's Pal, Jimmy Olsen, of all books? Well, you see, Kirby's whole plan at DC was mostly to do his own thing, but while he was working on his own thing, he agreed to do some DC Universe right away and it was as simple as Superman's Pal, Jimmy Olsen not having a regular creative team. Kirby didn't want someone to lose their job for him to take over, so he asked which books were free and clear and Jimmy Olsen was the answer.</p><p>The other notable thing sort of speaks to the snobbery of DC Comics at the time. DC was so obsessed with their characters being \"on brand\" that they had artist Al Plastino (longtime Superman artist and the co-creator of Supergirl) re-draw Superman's face in this comic book so that it would be \"on model.\" It's absurd. You bring over Jack Kirby, you do big ads for Jack Kirby coming to DC and then you...re-draw Jack Kirby's Superman? It's beyond absurd. Kirby wasn't a fan of it, but he was a good company guy, so he went along with it. DC had Vince Colletta ink Kirby at first and Colletta inked this issue. </p><p>Being his first issue at DC, Kirby wanted to really go overboard with new ideas, but first, he brought back an OLD idea. When he was first at DC in the 1940s, after leaving Timely Comics (now Marvel) in a contract dispute over Captain America royalties (or the lack thereof), Kirby and his partner, Joe Simon, went to DC and invented ANOTHER hit comic book series, with the Boy Commandos, a team of young kids working as, well, you know, commandos. The idea worked so well that Kirby and Simon then introduced a stateside version of the team called the Newsboy Legion, local newsboys who would also fight crime, along with their superhero guardian, the Guardian (who also knew the boys as the beat cop from their block). In Jimmy Olsen #133, Jimmy is sent to interview the Newsboy Legion, who are somehow still young kids (this later gets addressed)...</p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-133-1.jpg\"/></figure><p>Right after this, Kirby then introduced Morgan Edge, the new boss of both Jimmy and Clark Kent, as Edge owned both the Daily Bugle and the Galaxy Broadcasting System (GBS) where Edge made Clark Kent a TV news anchor. Edge was a slick talking executive, but he hid a dark secret, he secretly worked for a criminal organization known as Intergang! In this first issue, Edge arranges to have his own reporter, Clark Kent, murdered!</p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-133-2.jpg\"/></figure><p>Obviously, Kent is a bit harder to kill that most reporters. Jimmy, meanwhile, is having a good time with the Newsboy Legion and their super-fast flying car known as the Whiz Wagon. While flying with it, they come across the Outsiders, a sort of futuristic motorcycle gang. Jimmy inadvertently knocks out their leader and becomes the new head of the gang. When Superman comes to go investigate his missing pal, Jimmy and the gang have to let Superman know that things aren't what they appear....</p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-133-5.jpg\"/></figure><p>They even knock Superman out with a kryptonite gun! When Superman comes to, he discovers that the Outsiders are protecting a bizarre environment known as the Habitat. This is all tied with the DNA Project (later known as Project: Cadmus). As noted, Kirby was throwing so many different awesome new ideas at the wall at once and they all landed really well. </p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-133-6.jpg\"/></figure><p>The Outsiders are searching for a moving mountain and Jimmy heads off to help them find it (since he is sort of their new leader). Think of all the crazy stuff in  just this first issue and note that we haven't even met Morgan Edge's secret boss yet (hint, his name rhymes with Park Ride). What a start for the King!</p><p>If you folks have any suggestions for September (or any other later months) 2010, 1995, 1970 and 1945 comic books for me to spotlight, drop me a line at brianc@cbr.com! Here is the guide, though, for the cover dates of books so that you can make suggestions for books that actually came out in the correct month. Generally speaking, the traditional amount of time between the cover date and the release date of a comic book throughout most of comic history has been two months (it was three months at times, but not during the times we're discussing here). So the comic books will have a cover date that is two months ahead of the actual release date (so October for a book that came out in August). Obviously, it is easier to tell when a book from 10 years ago was released, since there was internet coverage of books back then.</p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 01 Sep 2020 01:44:50 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-jack-kirby-debut-header.jpg","linkMd5":"38db19648901576f250a372ab49a669c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn98@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-01-809_26136692f228b028.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":214644,"destBytes":214644,"author":"Brian Cronin","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-jack-kirby-debut-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn98@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-01-809_26136692f228b028.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-133-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn97@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-05-952_af679e084719570c.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-133-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn9@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-06-055_0e453ab9c523d26c.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-133-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn22@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-08-402_83ff26d192f2f815.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/jimmy-olsen-133-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn38@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-10-150_d7688789887e46a5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700503},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"BOFURI: 10 Things We Hope To See In Season 2 | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/bofuri-isekai-anime-season-two-wishlist/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Featured-Bofuri-Sally-and-Maple-Fighting-Mosters.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>BOFURI: I Don't Want to Get Hurt, so I'll Max Out My Defense</em>, is one of the newest explorations into anime's isekai genre. It follows the adventures of two best friends, known by their gamer aliases of Maple and Sally, as they play through a new virtual reality <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/best-mmorpg-anime-fans/\">MMORPG called NewWorld Online</a>. Maple, being new to games, doesn't want to experience any kind of pain at all while playing, and begins by dumping all of her experience points into her defense.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/isekai-manga-best-my-anime-list/\">10 Best Isekai Manga Of All Time (According To MyAnimeList)</a></span></p><p>It doesn't take long until she becomes a walking fortress, and while she insists that she's playing the game casually, she soon becomes its strongest player, stumbling across powerful skills along the way. With a new season rumored to be coming sometime during the latter half of this year, there are a handful of things we'd love to see once Maple, Sally, and the rest of her friends grace our screens once again.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>More Beast Companions</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Beast-Companions.jpg' /></figure><p>During NewWorld Online's second event, Maple and Sally managed to defeat a powerful boss and were rewarded with two eggs as a result. Both eggs hatched into tiny but powerful creatures, with Maple keeping the turtle for herself and Sally keeping the fox. Not only are these creatures extremely cute, but they've proven their usefulness in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/pokemon-battles-anime-greatest/\">battles, and are reminiscent of Pokémon</a> in that they can learn skills of their own through training.</p><p>While Sally and Maple are the only players shown to possess beast companions, there have to be more out there. Not only would the playing field be leveled if more players found their own companions, but fans would have the opportunity to see two of these creatures duke it out, further diversifying NewWorld Online's gameplay.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Maple Tree's Growth</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Members-of-Maple-Tree-Guild.jpg' /></figure><p>Like many MMORPGs, NewWorld Online places a huge emphasis on establishing guilds and growing them. As viewers have seen, some of the largest guilds are akin to armies. Maple's very own guild, Maple Tree, is one of the smallest in the game, but all of its members are powerhouses.</p><p>As Maple and her friends continue to explore this virtual world, it's almost inevitable that they'll come across other powerful players who wouldn't hesitate to join Maple Tree, especially given the fact that they're now recognized as one of the strongest guilds next to the Flame Emperors and the Holy Swords.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>New Kinds Of Events</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-and-Sally-Exploring.jpg' /></figure><p>NewWorld Online emphasizes its in-game events, with four occurring in <em>BOFURI</em>'s first season. This means that new events will be integral to season 2's plot, and hopefully, they are a lot different than the previous events.</p><p>The possibilities are endless: One could be another battle royale, except the map constantly changes with each day. Or perhaps players will be sorted into random teams and be forced to advance together through a string of boss battles. Or maybe an event in which players can only compete if they have a beast companion that they can then use to battle other players' beast companions. No matter what this next event might be, fans can't wait to see just how Maple will show the developers just how broken she still is.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>New Forms</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maples-Different-Forms.jpg' /></figure><p>NewWorld Online gives players an opportunity to become things they'd never become in reality. They can be swordsmen, wizards, and even blacksmiths, but Maple's found ways to become a goddess, a devil, and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/best-gundam-anime-ranked/\">even a Gundam</a>. After clearing extremely difficult quests, she's gained access to unique forms that grant her certain abilities that other players didn't even know existed.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/isekai-anime-things-make-sense-only-genre/\">10 Things That Only Make Sense In Isekai Anime</a></span></p><p>Given that she's already uncovered three forms in season 1, it's only a matter of time until she uncovers a new form to make her more of a threat than she already is.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Gamers Meeting In Real Life</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Swimming-with-her-Friends.jpg' /></figure><p>Many isekai anime make an effort to feature an episode where the gamers cross paths in reality. Given how much went down in season 1 of <em>BOFURI</em>, it would be amazing to see just what a powerful player like Mii is like in real life, and how far her whining gets her outside of NewWorld Online. Are some of the older players like Kasumi and Kuromu working or going to school as well?</p><p>Are any of these characters altering their appearances in the game and look drastically different in real life? Seeing Maple bump into someone she's only interacted with in the digital world (or even one of the game's developers for that matter) is definitely something fans would love to see in season 2.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>New Skills</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Using-Hydra.jpg' /></figure><p>As the series progressed, Maple, Sally, and their allies developed <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/insanely-powerful-characters-isekai-anime/\">powerful skills that helped them in difficult battles</a>, similar to any RPG. Many of these skills are pretty intriguing and unique to specific characters, but as Maple has shown everyone, there are unique skills and combinations that can only be discovered through exploring, along with trial and error.</p><p>Hopefully, season 2 introduces new skills that are not only extremely innovative, but showcase just how layered of a game NewWorld Online actually is.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>More Of \"Kaede\"</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Getting-Ready-to-Fight-in-Real-Life.jpg' /></figure><p>Most of <em>BOFURI </em>takes place in the virtual world of NewWorld Online, so much so that it becomes easy to forget that Sally and Maple have lives outside of the game.</p><p>In one episode of season 1, Kaede, Maple's real-world identity, allows her in-game habits to bleed into reality; at one point, she even attempts to use skills she possesses in the game during a dodgeball match, which leads to her getting hit by the ball (as expected). An episode diving more into how this game disrupts her normal life would be a great change of pace and go a long way in differentiating season 2 from its predecessor.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Greater Stakes</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Sally-Hurt.jpg' /></figure><p>Unlike most other isekai anime, the characters aren't trapped in the game by malicious developers. Dying in this game means, at the worst, a slight decrease in stats and abilities, but characters respawn with their gear in functioning order. In <em>BOFURI</em>, powerful rivalries don't mean a thing once events are over, and as seen in the final episode of season 1, Maple and her friends were able to hang out with their former adversaries as though they hadn't just been in the fight of their lives. This is due to the anime's low stakes: at worst, losing just means that players don't get a prize for winning an event.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/things-about-isekai-anime-make-no-sense/\">10 Things About Isekai Anime That Don't Make Sense</a></span></p><p>Hopefully, season 2 features a greater level of stakes for these characters in order to make viewers actually fear for them when they're in trouble. Perhaps dying can mean that players lose a valuable skill or random piece of equipment, or maybe someone makes a deal to walk away from the game forever if they lose a contest. So far, the anime feels just as inconsequential as playing any video game. This is what separates <em>BOFURI </em>from similar titles like <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/sword-art-online/\">Sword Art Online</a></em>, where the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/sword-art-online-best-charters-my-anime-list/\">lives of the players</a> are constantly on the line.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Maple's Defeat</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Gets-Hurt.jpg' /></figure><p>Despite not being a hardcore gamer, Maple was able to overcome every single opponent that challenged her. While she's had some close calls, she's never actually been defeated. It's odd to root for the protagonist's defeat, but almost every likable protagonist has suffered from one at some point. During his younger years, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dragon-ball-first-fights-goku-lost-why/\">Goku was defeated by Master Roshi during a martial arts tournament</a>, and even someone like Gon from <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/hunter-x-hunter/\">Hunter x Hunter</a></em> lost to his rival, Hisoka, when the two met in Heavens Arena.</p><p>These losses, though devastating, pushed both characters to take their training to the next level. If Maple has become so strong after playing \"casually,\" imagine just how ferocious of a player she'd be if she became a more serious-minded player after suffering her first loss.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Rematches Between Maple &#38; Mii/Payne</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Versus-Mii-and-Payne.jpg' /></figure><p>During the final episodes of season 1, Maple clashed against Mii and Payne, some of the strongest players in the game, next to Maple. Both put up a good fight but were no match for her transformations.</p><p>Hopefully, season 2 gives both of these characters a chance to redeem themselves. However, judging by the fact that a new transformation is most likely right around the corner for Maple, the results of each rematch might still be in her favor once again.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/re-zero-isekai-anime-recommendations-watch/\">Re:Zero - 10 Isekai Anime To Watch While Waiting For New Episodes Of Season 2</a> </span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 20:30:20 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Featured-Bofuri-Sally-and-Maple-Fighting-Mosters.jpg","linkMd5":"bee3668466278d3574c862353d61238c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn14@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-01-835_4ffd295c9221d029.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":146134,"destBytes":146134,"author":"Lavell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Featured-Bofuri-Sally-and-Maple-Fighting-Mosters.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn14@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-01-835_4ffd295c9221d029.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Beast-Companions.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn93@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-08-771_457dc6d33136ba09.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Members-of-Maple-Tree-Guild.jpg":null,"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-and-Sally-Exploring.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn93@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-12-253_779e0140c8ef9502.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maples-Different-Forms.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn53@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-06-996_ea501c38973081be.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Swimming-with-her-Friends.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn32@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-15-876_be9b8a1dad87637c.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Using-Hydra.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn37@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-11-791_8bc5061dd164dabb.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Getting-Ready-to-Fight-in-Real-Life.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn13@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-05-906_e79b4db10b5e1517.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Sally-Hurt.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn72@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-16-250_ff35a18946efbdc3.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Gets-Hurt.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn31@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-17-621_9da589b404ca2543.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bofuri-Maple-Versus-Mii-and-Payne.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn66@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-05-904_5ab73aa8d1074402.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700506},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"X-Men: A Fan-Favorite Villain Just Broke Krakoa's Biggest Rule","link":"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-omega-red-krakoa-biggest-rule/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/wolverine.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for </strong></em><strong><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/wolverine/\">Wolverine</a></strong><strong> #4 by Benjamin Percy, Viktor Bogdanovic, Matthew Wilson, VC's Corey Petit, and Tom Mueller, on sale now.</strong></p><p>Ever since the Dawn of X began, the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/x-men/\">X-Men</a>, their allies, and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-brings-shadow-king-krakoa/\">even their enemies</a> have gone through tremendous changes. Setting themselves apart from humanity, they’re working to claim what they see as their rightful place at the top of the world’s food chain by creating their own society with its own laws, including its most sacred law--no killing humans.</p><p>A few mutants, Wolverine included, are having more trouble adjusting than the others. The latest issue of <em>Wolverine</em> shows that the veteran X-Man isn’t alone, but some mutants, like the fan-favored Omega Red, are even more lost than Logan.</p><p>In Logan’s experience, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-wolverine-xavier-new-dream/\">good things like Krakoa never last</a>. This sense of dread is why Logan has had an especially hard time adjusting to the bright new future that the mutants have created for themselves, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-x-of-swords-apocalypse-betrayal/\">and he’s not alone</a>. He feels trapped, constantly watched by the Quiet Council or even the island itself. The island is a sanctuary to most mutants, but to Logan, it almost feels like a trap.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/empyre-x-men-multiple-man-genoshan-zombies/\">X-Men: [SPOILER] Has a GROSS Solution (and Huge Risk) to Marvel Zombies</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Wolverine-Omega-Red-1.jpg\"/></figure><p>In <em>Wolverine</em> #4, Logan once again leaves the island and visits the Red Tavern, a small bar up north that he considers to be his real sanctuary. But it’s clear that this sanctuary has been compromised when Logan gets the feeling that he’s met his fellow patrons before, growing mysteriously disoriented. He stumbles into the bathroom, finding a dead body and wondering not for the first time if this was his doing.</p><p>Having drugged Logan in the first place, the bar’s patrons certainly believe it is, tying Logan to a chair with the intent of taking him to the frozen lake and drowning him to circumvent his healing abilities. Despite Logan’s innocence, the humans are intent on killing him as a part of their Mutant Support Group that came together to cope over their collective suffering at the hands of mutants. All of them seek retribution against mutants for one reason or another, and plan on using Wolverine as a starting point.</p><p>As Logan sinks beneath the ice, the real killer, Omega Red, makes his presence known by hurling the decapitated head of one of the humans in front of his comrades. Omega Red rips through every single one of them without hesitation as Wolverine is forced to watch beneath the frozen water. As Wolverine sinks, his old foe claims that he understands why Logan comes to this spot, using his tentacles to drain the life from Logan beneath the frozen lake. Neither of them can stand the light of Krakoa, so they seek out the shadows to drink away their discomfort. But while Logan comes to drink away his sorrows with watered down beer and cheap whiskey, Omega Red has come to drink pain--Logan’s pain.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-force-mikhail-rasputin-return/\">X-Force Brings Back An Alpha-Level Mutant Powerhouse</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Omega-Red-Kills.jpg\"/></figure><p>This isn’t the first time a citizen of Krakoa has broken its most sacred rule. At the start of the Dawn of X, in <em>House of X</em> #6 by Jonathan Hickman and Pepe Laraz, the Quiet Council sentenced Wolverine’s greatest foe, Sabretooth, for his violent actions against humans while on a mission in the miniseries’ first issue. As retribution for the lives he’d taken, Victor Creed was cast down deep into the heart of Krakoa into a pit of exile to be kept in stasis until he can be reformed--or more likely until his nation needs him again.</p><p>With many of Wolverine's foes being hardened killers and the like, it is probable that at some point the Quiet Council will have to dispense justice once again sooner rather or later...possibly with Omega Red serving as the next example.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/wolverine-black-white-blood-all-star-talent-black-white-tales/\">Wolverine: Black, White &#38; Blood Enlists All-Star Talent For Untold Black And White Tales</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 17:20:39 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/wolverine.jpg","linkMd5":"93b3e791ccc2b6a663f11c2c3174df7c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn37@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-00-766_76e2b4dfda967812.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":242861,"destBytes":210868,"author":"Tristan Benns","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/wolverine.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn37@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-00-766_76e2b4dfda967812.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Wolverine-Omega-Red-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn61@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-08-490_b5bb52182106be87.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Omega-Red-Kills.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn55@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-10-141_b23f816978c5378f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700509},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Howard The Duck In Avengers: Endgame (& 9 Other MCU Easter Eggs We Forgot About)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/howard-the-duck-avengers-endgame-forgotten-mcu-easter-eggs/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Easter-Eggs-Feature.jpg\"/></figure><p>Whether you love them or hate them, the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marvel-cinematic-universe/\">MCU</a> deserves praise for the amount of detail placed into every movie and the nods that they make to the comics. While audiences don't always pick up on them, die-hard, eagle-eyed fans have meticulously scoured every film finding as many easter eggs as possible. Many of these references are regarded highly as proof of the franchise's dedication and respect for the source material while others have been forgotten.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-easter-eggs-hidden-plain-sight-mcu/\">Marvel: 10 Times It Hid Easter Eggs In Plain Sight</a></span></p><p>Maybe it's because fans overlooked these little details or thought that they didn't matter in the grand scheme. Either way, these little details are worth remembering even if they don't hint at what will come next. These are the ten MCU easter eggs that fans forgot about.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Howard the Duck in Endgame</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Howard-the-Duck-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/avengers-endgame/\">Avengers: Endgame</a> </em>is an astonishing milestone for the MCU bringing characters from the past films to face Thanos and his army. With so many characters, it makes sense that <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/howard-the-duck/\">Howard the Duck</a> would get lost in the crowd of Asgardians, Scavengers, and Wakandans. Even so, the Russo Brothers announced he was <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mcu-revelations-canon-not-movie-comic-tv/\">one of the Snap survivors</a> and snuck him into one of the crowd scenes. Maybe one of these days Howard will get a larger role but at least he played a part in one cinema's biggest moments.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>The Prowler in Homecoming</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Aaron-Davis-Spider-Man-1.jpg' /></figure><p>As the first <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spider-man/\">Spider-Man</a> movie in the MCU, <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spider-man-homecoming/\">Spider-Man: Homecoming</a> </em>managed to pack in a lot of characters from the comics into the film. From Scorpion to Betty Brant, and most importantly, Aaron Davis as played by Donald Glover. If the name sounds familiar, that's because the character is also known as the Prowler and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/miles-morales/\">Miles Morales's</a> uncle.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-spider-verse-things-didnt-know-trivia/\">Spider-Man: 10 Things You Didn't Know About The Comics Spider-Verse</a></span></p><p>Ever since <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/into-the-spider-verse/\"><em>Into the Spider-Verse</em></a>, fans have wondered if the MCU would cross-over with the animated hit. People were so busy wondering if animated Miles would make an appearance when the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-things-mcu-franchise-learn-into-spider-verse/\">MCU has a Miles</a>.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Dr. Strange Was Targeted By Hydra in Winter Soldier</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Jasper-Sitwell-Doctor-Strange-1.jpg' /></figure><p>The MCU tends to drop hints to future projects in varying degrees of subtlety. Sometimes they're subtle and hide easter eggs in the background while sometimes it's more overt. In <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/captain-america-the-winter-soldier/\"><em>Captain America: The Winter Soldier</em></a>, Jasper Sitwell gets interrogated about Hydra's plans for Project Insight. One of the names of possible threats he drops is <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/doctor-strange/\">Stephen Strange</a>, soon to be master of the mystic arts. While at this point Strange was still just a surgeon, the algorithm Arnim Zola designed could have predicted he wouldn't cooperate in the future. It was still a nice way to inform fans that the doctor was around the MCU.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Loki's \"Children\"</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Lokis-Kids.jpg' /></figure><p>When it comes to Norse mythology, the MCU has taken liberties with the source material when depicting the Asgardians. While the franchise has only skimmed from legends of old, they have hinted at some of the stranger parts of the lore. In <em>Thor, </em>Odin arrives in Jotunheim on an eight-legged horse, and in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/thor-ragnarock/\"><em>Thor: Ragnarok</em></a>, Hela ravages Asgard with a giant wolf. In Norse mythology, these creatures are two of Loki's children, Sleipnir and Fenrir, respectively. It's not clear if that is the case in the MCU but maybe Loki's spin-off might <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/loki-reasons-excited-worried-disney-plus-series/\">shed some light</a> on the matter.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>The Ten Rings Still Lingering</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Ten-Rings-Logo-Iron-Man.jpg' /></figure><p>With groups like Hydra and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/daredevil-worst-things-hand-has-done-marvel-universe/\">the Hand running around the MCU</a>, it's easy to forget about the first villainous organization: the Ten Rings. They haven't played a crucial role since <em>Iron Man,</em> they've remained relevant in the series.<em> </em>They were imitated in <em>Iron Man 3 </em>by Travis Slattery and Aldrich Killian and in <em>Ant-Man</em> one of their agents was witness to the reveal of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/yellowjacket/\">Yellowjacket</a> armor.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/shang-chi-things-fans-might-not-know/\">10 Things Fans Might Not Have Known About Shang-Chi</a></span></p><p>Fans have wondered who will be the next big threat in Phase 4 and while there are possibilities, the Ten Rings tend to be forgotten. That is, unless the conversation shifts to the upcoming <em>Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings</em>.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Cameron Klein</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Cameron-Klein-1-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>While the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/avengers/\">Avengers</a> tend to get all the glory for saving the world, many <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/shield-agents-all-time-ranked-comics/\">S.H.I.E.L.D. agents</a> that don't get the attention they deserve. Such as Cameron Klein, better known as the agent in <em>The Winter Soldier</em> who refused to launch Project Insight even as Crossbones threatened him at gunpoint. Fury must have valued Klein's resolve because Klein reappeared in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/age-of-ultron/\"><em>Avengers: Age of Ultron</em></a> as one of the S.H.I.E.L.D. agents aboard the helicarrier in Sokovia. The fact that Fury mentioned calling Klein at the end of <em>Avengers: Infinity War</em> shows how valuable he is to the agency. He may not be memorable but he's certainly dependable.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Captain America Kept His Monkey Drawing</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Dancing-Monkey-Easter-Egg-1.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/steve-rogers/\">Steve Rogers</a> is a man of many talents. In addition to his body being at peak strength, speed, and endurance, he happens to be a bit of an artist. Back in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/captain-america-the-first-avenger/\"><em>Captain America: The First Avenger</em></a>, when he wasn't gallivanting on stage he would doodle what was on his mind. In one scene, he drew himself as a monkey on a unicycle reflecting on his role in the war as a cheap attraction. He must have really liked that drawing because in <em>Captain America: Civil War</em> he has the page framed in his room. How he kept it in good condition is anyone's guess though it's possible Coulson kept in pristine condition.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Maria's Callsign</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Photon-Easter-Egg-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>Many fans were quick to scrutinize the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mcu-carol-danvers-comic-accurate/\">accuracy of </a><em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mcu-carol-danvers-comic-accurate/\">Captain Marvel</a> </em>for changing <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/carol-danvers/\">Carol Danvers's</a> call sign from Cheeseburger to Avenger but not her friend Maria's. Maria received a call sign like Carol except she received the moniker of Photon. Long-time fans should recall that in the comics this name doesn't belong to Maria but her daughter Monica when she became a superhero.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/captain-marvel-powers-potential/\">10 Things Captain Marvel Should Do With Her Powers (But Doesn't)</a></span></p><p>Monica was last seen as a little girl in the '80s and fans seemed to overlook the possibility that she might join her Aunt Carol on her next adventure and get powers for herself. If that's the case then she'll truly earn the title of Lieutenant Trouble.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Helen Cho in Age Of Ultron</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-Helen-Cho-2-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p><em>Age of Ultron</em> introduced a plethora of characters into the MCU from Ulysses Klau, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/scarlet-witch/\">Scarlet Witch</a>, and Helen Cho. For anyone that needs a reminder, Helen Cho is the scientist Ultron kidnaps to assist in building the body that would eventually become <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/vision/\">Vision</a>. While she may not play a significant role in the comics, she does become the mother of someone who does: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/comic-book-sidekicks-a-grade-heroes/\">Amadeus Cho</a>. A young prodigy that would be exposed to gamma rays and become the hero Brawn. If Helen is around, then her son might make an appearance down the line.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>In-Flight Movies in Far From Home</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvel-MCU-In-Flight-Movies-1-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>Even though he can do whatever a spider can, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/peter-parker/\">Peter Parker</a> gets bored on plane trips like everyone else. Fortunately in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spider-man-far-from-home/\"><em>Spider-Man: Far From Home</em></a>, his flight included in-flight movies. Before selecting the Iron Man documentary, a few options are presented for other films based on other subjects in the MCU like the Snap, Wakanda, and Hydra. Not only is it a fun way to make the MCU feel lived in but it also shows that Dr. Erik Selvig is doing well for himself ever since <em>Age of Ultron</em>. Though it certainly raises questions about what other ways entertainment has been influenced.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">Next: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mcu-black-widow-costume-hidden-details/\">MCU: 10 Hidden Details You Missed In Black Widow's Costume</a></span></p>\n                        \n
