Rui's mom lied dead in his arms, and you can see the anguish in his eyes and face.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Blood Webs</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-3.jpg' /></figure><p>His Demon Art centered around his ability to pump blood into his webbing, increasing the sharpness and cutting ability of it, making his attacks even deadlier than before. <a class=\"_e75a791d-denali-editor-page-rtfLink\" href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/akyjeff\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Akyjeff </a>shows that process here, Rui's hands becoming completely covered in red, coloring shifting to the webbing as he prepares to end whoever is trying to take his family away from him.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/5-ways-demon-slayer-and-bleach-are-similar-5-ways-theyre-completely-different/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">5 Ways Demon Slayer And Bleach Are Similar (&#38; 5 Ways They're Completely Different)</a></span></p><p>He does a great job of making Rui's eyes very vivid as well, pale sea-green around his eyelids bringing the red of his eyes out very well.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Love You</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-4.jpg' /></figure><p>As strange as it is considering he's a demon, much of Rui's actions were rooted in his desires to have a family, and in his own way, he loved the one he created. That love was just warped by what Muzan did to him, leading to the creature that <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/demon-slayer-tanjiro-dungeons-and-dragons-monsters/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Tanjiro</a> battled with. <a class=\"_e75a791d-denali-editor-page-rtfLink\" href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/under-draw-artist\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Under-draw-artist</a> adds some of that conflicted nature of the character into this image, with the heart in the webbing showing a level of care while his face remained blank and unfeeling.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Alone</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-5.jpg' /></figure><p>Despite the efforts Rui tried to make, be it becoming one of the moons or creating his spider family, he was always going to be alone. No one was going to care for him as his true family had done in the past. His creator saw him as nothing more than a pawn, and his fellow spiders only followed him out of fear rather than love. <a class=\"_e75a791d-denali-editor-page-rtfLink\" href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/kohkii\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Kohkii</a> captures a lot of that melancholy here, Rui looking dead inside as he stares up at his webbing dancing before his eyes.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Instability</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-6.jpg' /></figure><p>Rui was an incredibly unstable character whose desires didn't at all align with his actions. He wanted a family that loved him but only knew how to rule through fear. <a href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/rissineir\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Rissineir</a> does a good job showing that with the twisted smile on his face.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/demon-slayer-gyomei-himejima-anime-villains-defeat/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Demon Slayer: 10 Anime Villains Gyomei Himejima Could Defeat</a></span></p><p>You just imagine Nezuko refusing him as a brother, Rui gleefully preparing to punish her for it. The webbing all around him in the background only drives that point home further as that was his primary means of attack.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Spider</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-7.jpg' /></figure><p>While Father Spider was the only one who took on true animal-like qualities, <a class=\"_e75a791d-denali-editor-page-rtfLink\" href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/adeslowmoqueen\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Adeslowmoqueen</a> decided to go the extra mile with Rui as well. The legs sprouting from his back are almost translucent, blending into the background so nicely that you'd think they were nearly an apparition. His eyes are more prototypical anime style too, very wide and large, giving you a full view of the intricate design his eyes have. The colors are also so bright and vivid.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>I See You</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-8.jpg' /></figure><p>The fact <a href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/heroinecreative\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Heroinecreative</a> chose to do such an up-close image of Rui means the detail needs to be impeccable and it is here. The coloring of the eyes is so bright, eyelashes matching perfectly with the fingernail polish. It's close enough that you can see the lashes themselves as well. That pose makes it look like Rui is staring through his fingers like it's a microscope, examining his prey with the same cold demeanor a mad scientist would have.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Tears</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-9-1.jpg' /></figure><p>Judging from his eyes, this piece by <a class=\"_e75a791d-denali-editor-page-rtfLink\" href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/kumasan0214\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Kumasan0214 </a>is from the early parts of Rui's transformation, when he was first granted the ability to walk and move around. It's hard to know if those tears are from that fact or something else, as it seems like his parents are behind him. It's a rare image that shows Rui before he became the full-fledged demon seen in the show. It almost makes you <a class=\"_e75a791d-denali-editor-page-rtfLink\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tragic-sad-villain-origins-ranked/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">feel bad</a> for him, knowing how badly his image of a family was twisted.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Join Me</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-10.jpg' /></figure><p>The interesting part of Rui's character wasn't his powers or even the fact he was one of the lower moons, it's that he yearned to have Nezuko as a sister, obsessing over the fact. He was always looking to bring people into his fold, no matter what. It's why him being a spider demon worked so well. <a class=\"_e75a791d-denali-editor-page-rtfLink\" href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/katrinci\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Katrinci</a> does a great job of showing some of that yearning in his eyes, and with the fact, the web is spread so far between his fingertips, ready to trap those he wants to keep. The gloss in his hair is also very nice, the way the light bounces off it, make it seem almost like fronds.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/demon-slayer-vs-tokyo-ghoul-which-show-is-better/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Demon Slayer vs. Tokyo Ghoul: Which Show Is Better?</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 01 Sep 2020 02:00:39 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Header-Cropped.jpg","linkMd5":"72f2ffc8c65d96d579eadc74a2877757","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn83@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-00-721_3733aa67beff6e98.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":114764,"destBytes":114764,"author":"Anthony Mazzuca","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Header-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn83@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-00-721_3733aa67beff6e98.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slayer.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-17-141_d2bf54ad03d48a08.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn63@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-16-029_e1c30cf3fdb83b09.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-17-407_353b154a3006f05a.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn66@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-10-964_9edea126556cd6b1.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn83@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-16-222_ae7b0b991c4e737f.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn87@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-15-946_9140de937c18a9b3.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-7.jpg":null,"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn100@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-15-160_a64ad2e7e4769e69.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-9-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn61@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-05-878_b91f1357f08406d9.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Rui-Demon-Slaye-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn55@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-09-472_a7e9f6179fb3ce68.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700502},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"She-Hulk: How the Avenger Joined the Fantastic Four | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/she-hulk-joined-fantastic-four/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/She-Hulk-FF-feature.jpg\"/></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/she-hulk/\">She-Hulk</a> has <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/empyre-she-hulk-death-avengers/\">played a significant role</a> in the <em><a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/empyre\">Empyre</a></em> storyline. Her future is somewhat uncertain, but her past is just as tumultuous. Although Jennifer Walters is famously a member of the <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/avengers\">Avengers</a>, she was also a member of the <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/fantastic-four\">Fantastic Four</a> for a time.</p><p>Following <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/secret-wars\">Secret Wars</a>, She-Hulk became one of the first Marvel heroes to hold a spot on both teams' rosters. Here's what happened during her time with the Fantastic Four.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/avengers-she-hulk-breaks-bad/\">Avengers: One Of Marvel's Strongest Heroes Breaks Bad – And It's HORRIFYING</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/She-Hulk-Secret-Wars.jpg\"/></figure><p>Shortly into her tenure as an Avenger, Jennifer Walters became one of many heroes to be gathered by the Beyonder to take part in the Secret Wars -- an enigmatic clash of heroes and villains for the entertainment of one extra-dimensional entity. While the Beyonder's tournament led to several iconic firsts -- the first appearance of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/every-spider-woman-marvel/\">Julia Carpenter</a> as <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/spider-woman\">Spider-Woman</a>, the symbiote black suit that would later become <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/venom\">Venom</a> -- She-Hulk joining the Fantastic Four is an unexpected one.</p><p>In Jim Shooter and Mike Zeck's <em>Secret Wars</em> #12, Ben Grimm decides to stay behind on Battleworld for awhile. The Thing, forever forced to remain a rocky monster, learns he can return to a somewhat human form while on the other planet. Ergo, he decides to stay behind and the Fantastic Four replaces him with She-Hulk.</p><p>She-Hulk becomes a reserve member of the Avengers while fighting alongside the Fantastic Four for 35 issues. She leaves when Ben returns, though the two do bond over drinks and a friendly bar brawl to help the Thing vent his emotional conflicts in the process.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-wolverine-new-fantastic-four/\">Marvel Officially Assembles A NEW Fantastic Four</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/She-Hulk-Fantastic-Four.jpg\"/></figure><p>While fighting alongside the Fantastic Four, She-Hulk is so bombarded by S.H.I.E.L.D. Radiation that for an extended period of time, it's impossible for her to transform into her human form. However, because She-Hulk likes being She-Hulk, this doesn't prove to be that much of a problem.</p><p>While with the team, she fights fought like Doctor Octopus, <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/doctor-doom\">Doctor Doom</a> and Mephisto. She-Hulk was there when the Fantastic Four first encounter Terminus, an alien that battled the Celestials themselves. Her incredible strength helps stop Terminus from obliterating the planet, though it's ultimately Reed Richards who puts the villain down. She-Hulk is also a member of the team when <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/spider-man\">Spider-Man</a> learns his black costume is a symbiote and, later, when the symbiote escapes custody in John Byre's  <em>Fantastic Four</em> #274 as it attempts to once again bond with Peter before finding a new host in Eddie Brock.</p><p>Arguably most important of all, however, is the when She-Hulk, the Fantastic Four and the Avengers find <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/jean-grey\">Jean Grey</a>'s psychic cocoon, where the mutant lurked following the creation of her Phoenix Force body. Shortly after that, She-Hulk rejoined the Avengers and drifted away from the Fantastic Four. However, she remained one of the team's most frequent susbtitute members for many of the ensuing years.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fantastic-four-joe-sinnott-mystery-half-page-inks/\">What Is The Mystery Of Joe Sinnott's Half-Page Of Fantastic Four #6 Inks?</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 16:20:52 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/She-Hulk-FF-feature.jpg","linkMd5":"bbafb728b9961615e27f34de6c54da86","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn94@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-03-191_9ec905fcb42c34d7.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":172048,"destBytes":172048,"author":"Anthony Gramuglia","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/She-Hulk-FF-feature.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn94@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-03-191_9ec905fcb42c34d7.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/She-Hulk-Secret-Wars.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn29@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-08-303_6b299015a7c4aa41.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/She-Hulk-Fantastic-Four.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn12@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-15-800_776cbdb939305bb8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700509},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Dragon Ball: Every Major Character Who Fought With A Weapon | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/dragon-ball-main-characters-fought-with-weapons/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dbw-fi.jpg\"/></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Weapons and </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/dragon-ball\">Dragon Ball</a> </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">don’t exactly go hand in hand. Most of the series’ combat revolves around fairly traditional martial arts, with an increase in Ki attacks and spectacle as the story matured. Most every character has a signature Ki attack, but very few have a signature weapon. Which isn’t to say </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> hasn’t had its share of weapon wielding warriors.</span></p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ultimate-butoden-dragon-ball-games-never-heard-of/\">Ultimate Butoden &#38; 9 Other Dragon Ball Games You’ve Never Heard Of</a></span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In fact, Goku was originally designed </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">with </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">a weapon in mind. Before Goku began learning martial arts under Roshi, he fought with the Nyoibo– </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/dragon-ball-z\">Dragon Ball</a></span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">’s signature weapon. But he wasn’t the only character to wield a weapon. With a preference towards swords &#38; staffs, </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/dragon-ball-super\">Dragon Ball</a> </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">has featured a surprising number of weapons for characters throughout the years. </span></p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Son Goku (Nyoibo)</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/power-pole.jpg' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Nyoibo– also known as the Power Pole in Funimation’s English dub– is a weapon Goku inherited from his grandfather, Gohan, before the start of the series. Along with his tail, the Nyoibo is one of Goku’s defining features in the first story arc. The first proper martial arts fight in the series even includes Goku clashing the Nyoibo against Yamcha’s Liuyedao. </span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">While the Nyoibo would be understandably sidelined for the 21st Tenkaichi Budokai, Goku used it a few times in the Red Ribbon Army arc. After this point, Goku’s focus on martial arts meant he didn’t need to use the Nyoibo as a weapon anymore. The last time the Nyoibo is used in the manga is when Goku connects Karin Tower to God’s Palace. The last time it’s seen, however, is on Goku’s back when he reunited with everyone at the 23rd Tenkaichi Budokai. </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Yamcha (Liuyedao)</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Yamcha-vs-Goku.jpg' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A desert bandit, it only makes sense Yamcha is introduced with a weapon. While he has access to the Roga Fufu Ken– one of the first named techniques in </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">– his first fight sees heavy use of his Liuyedao. Yamcha never uses his Liuyedao again following his battle with Goku, but it’s an exciting introduction to the character. </span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Yamcha also busts out a rocket launcher at one point, taking out the Dragon Team’s car. As </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">continued and Yamcha faded into the background, there would be less &#38; less opportunities for him to use weapons. Virtually all of Yamcha’s battles after this point are fought in tournament settings. </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Master Roshi (Staff)</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Dragon-Ball-Master-Roshi-Buff.jpg' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A martial arts master, it makes sense Master Roshi wouldn’t need to fight with a weapon. In fact, throughout the original </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, the only time he ever uses his staff as a weapon is in his brief fight against Captain Dock &#38; his men during the Red Ribbon Army arc. Come </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball Super</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, however, and you’d think Roshi’s staff was a key part of his skill set. </span></p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dragon-ball-piccolo-bests-fights-original-series/\">Dragon Ball: Piccolo’s Best Fight In Every Arc (In The Original Series)</a></span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Both </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Resurrection F </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">and the Moro arc feature Roshi using his staff to fight opponents. While this does make sense in some capacity considering Roshi is far outclassed by the current Dragon Team, the manga’s Universe Survival arc does go to greath lengths to showcase Roshi’s skill in light of his age. Either way, it’s a means of </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">to get interesting choreography out of a character who stopped fighting at the Piccolo Daimao arc. </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Son Gohan (Sword)</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Gohan-with-sword.jpg' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Gohan very briefly wields a sword in the Saiyan arc, but it’s almost iconic to the character– if only because it’s paired with a demonic version of Goku’s own gi. In the manga, Gohan only ever uses the sword to cut off a dinosaur’s tail, the story skipping past most of Gohan’s time in the wild. </span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The anime revels in this period of </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">history, though, showcasing almost everything Gohan went through in order to begin training with Piccolo. Gohan’s sword is as much a weapon as it is a tool, and it’s even comparable to Goku’s early relationship with the Nyoibo. </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Future Trunks (Sword)</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Dragon-Ball-Z-Kakarot-Future-Trunks.png' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Aside from the hand blasters used by Frieza’s men, the next time a weapon is seen after Gohan’s sword in </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">isn’t until Future Trunks’ introduction in the Cell arc. Despite being a spacebound story, the Namek arc is pure martial arts from start to finish. Trunks’ sword introduces a new edge to combat that had been missed. </span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Paired with his sheer tenacity, Trunks makes excellent use of his sword– cutting Frieza into pieces before obliterating him with a Ki attack. Unfortunately, Trunks’ sword is shattered during the fight with the Artificial Humans. 18 grabs the blade and shatters it before Trunks can do much of anything. </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Dabra (Dadao)</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/dabura.jpg' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Even though he doesn’t use his dadao enough to be associated with it (his signature attack is petrifying spit, after all,) Dabra’s sword is still an iconic part of his character design. The King of Hell wielding a dadao only makes sense. It’s just a pity he doesn’t get to use it all that much before he ultimately dies. </span></p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dragon-ball-z-gohan-vs-goku-better-protagonist/\">Dragon Ball Z: 5 Reasons Why Gohan Should’ve Been The Protagonist (&#38; 5 Reasons Why Goku Was Good Enough)</a></span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dabra uses his sword against Gohan and later Majin Buu, but the blade does nothing to his opponent both times. In the case of Gohan, their fight ends shortly after the fact. With Buu, the Djinn turns Dabra into a cookie &#38; eats him almost immediately. </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Son Gohan (Z-Sword)</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Dragon-Bal-Z-Gohan-Destroys-Z-Sword.jpg' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Toriyama’s passion for swords rear their head in the Majin Buu arc, with Gohan even pulling out a weapon right out of Arthurian Legend on Kaioshin’s home world. Stuck in its pedestal, the Z Sword is deemed too heavy to be pulled out, but Gohan’s able to force his way through the ordeal by turning Super Saiyan. </span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Z Sword is set up as the weapon destined to defeat Majin Buu, so having it break in two makes for quite a shock. That said, the destruction leads to Rou Kaioshin’s unsealing. While the elder Kaioshin is able to unlock Gohan’s latent potential, Evil Buu is one step ahead of the Dragon Team and the Z Sword’s efforts go to waste. </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Future Trunks (Super Sword)</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Future-Trunks-with-his-Sword-of-Hope.jpg' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Like Gohan, Future Trunks gets to wield the Z Sword during his Majin Buu crisis. It also breaks, but Dabra’s petrification shatters the blade completely, presumably killing the Rou Kaioshin. Trunks loses the Z Sword in the process, but he’s able to defeat both Dabra and Bobbidi before Majin Buu can be revived. </span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Some time after, Trunks manages to get his hands on a wider blade that he uses throughout all of </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball Super</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. The sword breaks during his fight against Zamasu and Goku Black near the end of the arc, but the anime has Trunks channel what seems to be Genki into the sword in order to land the finishing blow on Merged Zamasu. </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Merus (Angel Staff)</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Merus-vs-Moro.jpg' /></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">All the Galactic Patrolmen use blasters to make up for their lack of Ki, but Merus was in a league of his own. Of course, this only ended up being the case because Merus is actually an angel. With the Moro arc nearing its conclusion, Merus recently gave his life in an attempt to teach Goku Ultra Instinct one last time. </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">During his fight with Moro, Merus uses his angel staff as a weapon– ranging from a spear, to a sniper rifle. Merus’ battle makes for some of the best fight choreography </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dragon Ball Super </span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">has had in a while and a large reason why is the creative use of his angel staff.</span></p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dragon-ball-super-manga-anime-similarities-differences/\">Dragon Ball: 5 Things They Changed From Dragon Ball Super To The Manga (&#38; 5 That Stayed The Same)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 01 Sep 2020 00:00:30 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dbw-fi.jpg","linkMd5":"1e307c75b59b872199e791a53216dd14","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn26@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-02-277_ac8f3091564a69f2.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":116922,"destBytes":116922,"author":"Renan Fontes","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dbw-fi.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn26@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-02-277_ac8f3091564a69f2.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/power-pole.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn54@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-08-300_5530a2592eefc032.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Yamcha-vs-Goku.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn14@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-09-783_4ae7838a72b25738.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Dragon-Ball-Master-Roshi-Buff.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn95@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-12-967_55ed3dc7e0366f80.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Gohan-with-sword.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn14@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-11-650_bd648ea3502e1d3b.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Dragon-Ball-Z-Kakarot-Future-Trunks.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn80@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-10-402_b3dda29ae15dc9db.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/dabura.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn42@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-07-556_57037f0adbcf0e1a.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Dragon-Bal-Z-Gohan-Destroys-Z-Sword.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn88@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-16-253_96701bbce1a8f539.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Future-Trunks-with-his-Sword-of-Hope.jpg":null,"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Merus-vs-Moro.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn65@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-07-116_de8263efb9fc78e8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700504},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Shonen Jump’s Cancellation of Time Paradox Ghostwriter Is Unsurprising","link":"https://www.cbr.com/shonen-jumps-cancellation-of-time-paradox-ghostwriter-is-unsurprising/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/time-paradox-ghostwriter.jpg\"/></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/time-paradox-ghostwriter/\"><em>Time Paradox Ghostwriter</em></a> has <a href=\"https://twitter.com/WSJ_manga/status/1298554498672197632?s=20\">reportedly been axed</a> by <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/shonen-jump/\"><em>Weekly Shonen Jump</em></a>. It's been a controversial series since it began serialization, with a vocal fanbase making their dislike of the series' exploration of plagiarism known. The author, Kenji Ichima, was forced to disable replies on social media due to negative comments about the series. What adds to the discourse is that the main character, a male creator, steals the work of a young girl who spends over a decade trying to perfect a story that she can be proud of and is excited to show other people. Plagiarism of someone's own original creative work goes against the moral compass of many and it was unnerving to see how the series attempted to build excuses to make it seem okay.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/time-paradox-ghostwriter-new-shonen-jump-manga/\">Shonen Jump's Newest Manga Is About... a New Shonen Jump Manga</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Untitled-design-17.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>Time Paradox Ghostwriter</em> had a great start following Teppei Sasaki, a struggling artist trying to become a professional manga artist with <em>Shonen Jump</em>, but constantly has his ideas rejected. The beginning of this series shows the inner workings of how <em>Shonen Jump</em>, and other manga publishers, operate behind the scenes. The audience sees the many challenges that comes with getting a published one-shot, much less a full running series, putting them on full display and giving readers a renewed appreciation for their favorite manga, the mangaka behind them and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/how-you-can-support-anime-industry/\">the entire team who work hard </a>to get a new chapter out every week. Teppei's struggles as a creator are also very realistic, trying to find his unique voice as an artist as he resiliently tries to live out his dream while trying to make ends meet.</p><p>The series takes a turn when he finally finds success by plagiarizing \"White Knight,\" the work of a young girl named Itsuki Aino, when a microwave time machine sends Teppei her groundbreaking manga from 10 years in the future. Teppei recognizes that what he's doing is wrong, but reasons that it's somehow okay to steal Itsuki's hard work and creativity, even trying to trace her artwork at one point to replicate her success. No, he does not accept profit from the manga due to feeling terrible about his actions, but that still doesn't change the fact that he does it for personal gain' recognition, praise and prestige are all still forms of payment. Itsuki surrenders the 'White Knight' story to Teppei and becomes determined to create another <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/manga\">manga </a>that can surpass it. To top it all off, Itsuki is going to die from exhaustion due to overworking herself as a manga artist and Teppei has to somehow prevent this by plagiarizing some more.</p><p>Although this type of story did not sit well with readers, there is still some merit to it. <em>Shonen Jump's </em>usual fare are action-packed stories with powerful, immutable heroes. a few exceptions like <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-promised-neverland/\"><em>The Promised Neverland</em></a>, but <em>Time Paradox Ghostwriter</em> is a shonen-supernatural series that fans of the manga magazine don't typically get to see serialized. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/shonen-jump-manga-titles-canceled/\">Despite its short run </a>and controversial topic of choice, <em>Time Paradox Ghostwriter</em> had great visuals and a premise that <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/shonen-protagonists-changed-for-the-better/\">broke the cookie cutter <em>Shonen Jump</em> formula</a>. The series could be a gateway for future stories with unique concepts that push the envelope more than what's been serialized in the past. As long as the mangaka nail the execution, these stories will be the next evolution of <em>Jump — </em>and <em>Time Paradox Ghostwriter </em>will have paved the way.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-best-shonen-manga-created-by-women/\">Jumping the Boys Club: The Best Shonen Manga Created By Women</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 20:00:26 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/time-paradox-ghostwriter.jpg","linkMd5":"e6bf9e53b781645b2807b75b7b7962af","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn16@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-00-658_56ea7d01a10516f2.webp","destWidth":1600,"destHeight":800,"sourceBytes":303326,"destBytes":256872,"author":"Nerissa Rupnarine","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/time-paradox-ghostwriter.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn16@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-00-658_56ea7d01a10516f2.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Untitled-design-17.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn73@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-05-928_31a61ceae0d5b3aa.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700507},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Marvel Reschedules Non-Stop Spider-Man #1 for January, Teases Bachalo's Die-Cut Variant","link":"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-reschedules-non-stop-spider-man-1-for-january-teases-bachalos-die-cut-variant/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/non-stop-spider-man-header.jpg\"/></figure><p>Marvel Comics has pushed <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/non-stop-spider-man/\">Non-Stop Spider-Man</a></em>'s release date back to next year, but its creative team has teased a new cover as well as the action held within the pages.</p><p>Series artist Chris Bachalo will provide a die-cut variant for the first issue. The first look at the variant shows Spidey in a swinging pose. The full cover will be revealed at a future date, with artist David Finch providing the cover art for the first issue.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-ps4-city-at-war/\">Spider-Man: How City at War Brought the PS4 Game to Comics</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/245308-1416152-2.jpg\"/></figure><p>“Non-Stop Spider-Man is, for me, the best of what Marvel comics can be: relentless action, epic storytelling, mind-melting art, and relevant themes, all grounded by the heart and soul of one of my all-time favorite characters, Spider-Man,” Kelly said while describing the series. Bachalo added that Kelly was one of his favorite writers to work with and Spider-Man was one of his favorite heroes to draw and that the book provided him a chance to draw intense action sequences.</p><p><em>Non-Stop Spider-Man</em> features the web-slinger going up against several of his enemies, with the creators promising breakneck action in each issue. The series was originally set to debut this June, but the COVID-19 pandemic temporarily halted the shipping of comics.</p><p><em>Non-Stop Spider-Man</em> will go on sale in January 2021 from Marvel Comics.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/non-stop-spider-man-ongoing-series/\">Non-Stop Spider-Man Swings Into New Ongoing Title From Kelly, Bachalo</a></span></p><p>(<em>via <a href=\"https://www.previewsworld.com/Article/245308-Get-an-Adrenaline-Rush-this-January-with-Non-Stop-Spider-Man\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">PreviewsWorld</a></em>)</p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 19:52:34 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/non-stop-spider-man-header.jpg","linkMd5":"9d9c25ea83c22715fe122f6c7e054351","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn45@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-00-734_2016f779722e78d6.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":322024,"destBytes":287574,"author":"Collier Jennings","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/non-stop-spider-man-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn45@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-00-734_2016f779722e78d6.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/245308-1416152-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn9@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-10-678_c38e2a41485b0968.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700507},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Dungeons & Dragons: Policing Accessibility Is Not in the Spirit of Co-Op","link":"https://www.cbr.com/dungeons-dragons-policing-accessibility-not-spirit-co-op/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dungeon-and-dragons.jpg\"/></figure><p>At its core, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/dungeons-and-dragons/\">Dungeons &#38; Dragons</a> is a collaborative tabletop experience in which players can transform themselves into elves, dwarves, satyrs, genasi and other mythical beings so as to do things that are impossible in the real world. However, when the topic turns to inclusiveness, some <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>fans become decidedly unwilling to allow others to play the game how they want.</p><p>Recently, a <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dd-fan-created-combat-wheelchair-inclusivity/\">fan made creation combat wheelchair</a>, which allows players to create a character who uses a wheelchair for their <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>game, went viral. Such <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dungeons-dragons-build-campaign-first-town/\">homebrews that change aspects</a> of <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>have been a key part of the game and it's community for years, because the gameplay system is meant to be malleable and allow for changes that fit a player's wants and desires. While most were positive about the combat wheelchair, a number of players argued the rule-set wasn't in the spirit of the game.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dungeons-dragons-mythic-odysseys-theros-pantheon/\">D&#38;D: Who Are the Gods in the Pantheon of Theros?</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dnd-press-tasha-cover-header.png\"/></figure><p><em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>is fundamentally about gathering with a group of friends and creating a fun experience that, in the words of <a href=\"https://twitter.com/JeremyECrawford/status/1296481985959989253?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Lead Designer Jeremy Crawford</a>, \"weave fantasy tales for our mutual bliss.\" In a fantasy world in which anything can happen, the idea of limiting what one can do because of an erroneous perception that the rules do not allow for it directly violates the spirit of the game. Instead, it's the responsibility of players to find ways to help those around them enjoy the game to the utmost. Choosing to police accessibility by telling someone that their character cannot reflect the existence and experience of someone in the real world in a novel way that fits with <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons</em>' fantasy setting is ridiculous.</p><p>Critiques like those received by the combat wheelchair are all too common in nerd/geek spaces, which often find ways to exclude people for their gender identity, sexual preference and/or race. However, <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>should be a space free from such concerns and instead allow players to approach the game no matter who they are. Through the magic of imagination, all things are possible, and to choose to limit what one can do based on ableist, homophobic, sexist, transphobic and/or racist basis are entirely at odds with the very reason so many love <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons</em>, which is its ability to facilitate stories and experiences.</p><p>This isn't to say <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>has always been a model of inclusivity. Until 1989's <em>Advanced Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>2nd Edition, the game contained fundamental differences between men and women that play heavily into notions of gender essentialism. Those were later done away with, and <a href=\"https://archive.org/stream/enword_gary_gygax_qa_threads/enweggqa08_djvu.txt\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">creator Gary Gygax</a> noted the idea \"doesn't make a great deal of sense\" in a fantasy game. Race has also been an issue for quite a while, with the game potentially turning people off due to white supremacist notions inherent in its depiction of various races. For its part,<em> Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>publisher <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dungeons-and-dragons-representation-inclusivity-plans/\">Wizards of the Coast is also taking steps</a> to address the game's problematic approach to race.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/wwe-xavier-woods-dungeons-dragons-pax-online-panel/\">WWE's Xavier Woods Headlines Dungeons &#38; Dragons PAX Online Panel</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Dungeons-Dragons-Evil.jpg\"/></figure><p>Despite resistance from some segments of the fanbase, the future of <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>is inclusivity. Wizards of the Coast has had a lot of success in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dungeons-and-dragons-why-5e-successful-new-players/\">bringing new players into fifth edition</a>, due in part both to the prevalence of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dungeons-dragons-actual-play-shows-boosting-lgbtq-representation/\">actual-play shows</a> and this increased focus on inclusivity. The very makers of the game understand that to police accessibility and keep people away from <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons</em> by not allowing them to do stories their way is ridiculous and not the way forward.</p><p>Fundamentally, <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>is a gameplay system designed to facilitate adventures in a fantasy world that is <em>whatever </em>a group makes of it. The game is not a static document to which one needs to adhere religiously. Instead, <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>is designed to undergo revisions and to change. The beauty of the game is not in dogmatically following the rules, but deciding when the system can be improved to better facilitate the needs and wants of the group. Policing accessibility does not uphold some nebulous Platonic Ideal about what <em>Dungeons &#38; Dragons </em>is and isn't. Rather, it violates the most fundamental tenets of the game: Pursue your bliss and help others find theirs.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dungeons-dragons-tashas-cauldron-everything-sourcebook/\">Dungeons &#38; Dragons Announces Tasha's Cauldron of Everything Sourcebook</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 16:15:51 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dungeon-and-dragons.jpg","linkMd5":"77f86dfe253e12a903a61822453ce8fa","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn77@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-03-180_df871c2c67879253.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":88218,"destBytes":88218,"author":"Liam Nolan","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dungeon-and-dragons.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn77@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-03-180_df871c2c67879253.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dnd-press-tasha-cover-header.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn58@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-14-587_f5994df6ecebbb8b.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Dungeons-Dragons-Evil.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn50@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-11-800_3a8de88503199c75.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700509},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Punisher: 5 Times He Went Full Villain (& 5 Evil Villains He Killed)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/punisher-times-he-was-a-villain-vs-foes-he-felled-mandarin-barracuda-kasyckla/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/punisher-feature-5-villains-killed-n-5-times-he-was-one-Cropped.jpg\"/></figure><p>The <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-punisher/\">Punisher </a>was always a morally grey character. In fact, he started out as a villain, attempting to kill Spider-Man (who he mistakenly thought was a killer too). Frank Castle's entire approach to life has been to kill people so villainous they need to be put down.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/punisher-frank-castle-craziest-gadgets-used/\">Punisher: 10 Craziest Gadgets He Ever Used</a></span></p><p>In recent years, his symbol has been misappropriated by numerous groups espousing extreme forms of violence, many of whom admire his use of unrestrained lethal force. However, the Punisher sees himself as a villain and has even told people using his symbol that he will kill them if they do not stop. More than once, Frank Castle has crossed over from that morally grey area and become a full villain, but he has also managed to execute some truly heinous villains.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Full Villain: Vietnam</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/vietnam.jpg' /></figure><p>Frank Castle fought in Vietnam, where he gained the skills that allowed him to eventually become the Punisher. A common narrative acknowledges that the United States entered into the Vietnam War without proper preparation or understanding, resulting in an absolute disaster of war crimes, civilian deaths, and widespread human suffering.</p><p>While many soldiers were horrified by what they encountered in the jungles of Vietnam, Frank Castle reveled in the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-comics-the-punisher-best-fights-ranked/\">violence </a>of war. He killed for the joy of it, even killing soldiers on his own side.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Villain He Killed: Mandarin</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mandarin-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>The Mandarin was one of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/bane-vs-punisher-win-lose-fight/\">most powerful </a>humans in the Marvel Universe. With his ten magic rings, he had the ability to unleash incredibly destructive forces and even control the minds of others.</p><p>Then the Punisher shot him with a magic bullet. It seemed the only thing that could get past the Mandarin's defenses was a rare arcane sniper round, but the Punisher was more than happy to find the<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-punisher-5-weapons-frank-castle-always-carries-5-he-only-got-to-use-once/\"> right weapon </a>for the mission.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Full Villain: Secret Empire</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Secret-Empire-7-7-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>The infamous image of Captain America saying \"Hail Hydra\" is so notorious it instantly became a meme. It also led to Cap taking over the United States and the globe as part of a fascist insurrection with the backing of Hydra.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/darkest-punisher-stories-ever-marvel/\">The Punisher's 10 Darkest Stories Of All Time</a></span></p><p>People later learned that a Cosmic Cube had altered reality to bring about the evil Cap, but the Punisher never knew this. To Frank Castle, there was<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-punisher-frank-castle-facts-trivia/\"> no higher ideal </a>of virtue than Captain America, and so Frank became a soldier enforcing the will of the fascist regime.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Villain He Killed: Barracuda</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/barracuda-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>Barracuda was first introduced in the <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/alias-marvel-max-punisher-comics/\">Punisher MAX</a></em> series by Garth Ennis as a <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-comics-venom-punisher-fan-art/\">dark</a> reflection of the Punisher. The gold-toothed mercenary was guilty of just about every crime there was a name for, boasting about taking part in murder, cannibalism, and torture.</p><p>In short, Barracuda was a younger, tougher soldier with all of Castle's skills and none of his morality. Obviously, Frank Castle could not allow such a man to go on living.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Full Villain: Breaking Daredevil's Spirit</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Daredevil-Punisher-chains-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/daredevil/\">Daredevil </a>and Punisher have a long shared history. In one iconic story, Punisher chained Daredevil up on a rooftop. Meanwhile, Castle aimed his sniper rifle at a target.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-punisher-vs-daredevil-who-would-win-marvel/\">The Punisher Vs Daredevil: Who Would Win?</a></span></p><p>To complicate things, Punisher gave his bound captive a handgun. Either Daredevil could shoot Frank Castle to prevent the assassination, or else allow Punisher to shoot his target--either way, being complicit in murder. When Daredevil did try to shoot him, he found the firing pin tampered with. The Devil of Hell's Kitchen lost a little bit of his soul and Frank still got away with murder.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Villain He Killed: Nicky Cavella</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/nicky-cavella-slain-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>After the Punisher nearly <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mcu-jon-bernthal-punisher-comic-accurate-comparison/\">destroyed </a>the entire New York Mafia, they brought in a capo from Boston, Nicky Cavella, to help them. Cavella's sociopathic cruelty had previously gotten him banished from New York, meaning there was no line he would not cross.</p><p>The mafioso killed a number of government workers to get to Castle. When that failed, he defiled the graves of Castle's wife and kids, sending video footage to the media. Punisher captured Cavella, marched him into the woods, gut-shot him, and left him to suffer a slow death.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Full Villain: War Machine</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/war-machine-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>Nick Fury gave Punisher access to the War Machine armor to overthrow a genocidal regime that several ex-SHIELD agents had helped back. Frank Castle did what he does best, killing untold people along the way. He provoked a nuclear incident, something he had been repeatedly warned would happen.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-punisher-war-machine-armor-facts-trivia/\">The Punisher: 10 Things Fans Didn't Know About His War Machine Armor</a></span></p><p>Upon his return to the US, Frank fought most of the superhero community. He even battled Carol Danvers, clad in the armor her dead lover used to wear.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Villain He Killed: Kasyckla</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/k-frost-giant-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>The villain Kasyckla was a frost giant who participated in the invasion of Earth during the <em>War of the Realms</em>. As a massive, supernatural monster, the giant <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/joker-vs-punisher-who-would-win-marvel-dc-comics/\">slaughtered</a> indiscriminately, orphaning many children in the process.</p><p>Punisher stole one of Thor's goats, hitched it to his van, and chased the giant across the 10 Realms. Then he eviscerated Kasyckla with a magic sword. Anything for those poor orphaned children.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Full Villain: Killing Off Humanity</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/the-end-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>The story <em>Punisher: The End</em> showed a possible future where nuclear war had <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-punisher-frank-castle-embarrassing-losses/\">annihilated</a> most of the world's population. After Frank Castle crossed the apocalyptic hellscape of the US, he found his way into the bunker of some of the survivors.</p><p>Castle realized that the people who survived in the bunker were the same government and military officials responsible for the war. They also possessed the frozen embryos necessary to restart all of humanity and save the world. But they had helped kill billions and so Castle determined they needed to be punished. He executed all of them, dooming humanity in the process.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Villain He Killed: Zakharov</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/man-of-stone-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>General Nikolai Alexandrovich Zakharov oversaw some of the cruelest atrocities of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. He orchestrated the mass murder of women and children, even personally throwing a baby off a mountainside. His cold hard unmoving cruelty earned him the nickname \"the Man of Stone\"</p><p>Decades later, Zakharov set his sites on Frank CastleBoth men traveled to Afghanistan to confront one another. After a prolonged struggled, the Punisher stood over the Man of Stone and stove in his skull with a rock.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT:<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/punisher-marvel-heroes-respect-despise-love-hate-reasons/\"> The Punisher: 5 Marvel Heroes Who Respect Him (&#38; 5 Who Despise Him)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 22:00:55 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/punisher-feature-5-villains-killed-n-5-times-he-was-one-Cropped.jpg","linkMd5":"a847f55da7723649008f7e474ccd645a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn9@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-00-710_f96b2b408437532f.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":214814,"destBytes":214814,"author":"Theo Kogod","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/punisher-feature-5-villains-killed-n-5-times-he-was-one-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn9@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-00-710_f96b2b408437532f.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/vietnam.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn6@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-05-955_a00943af20c5b191.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mandarin-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn33@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-13-329_a5da933791693da4.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Secret-Empire-7-7-Cropped.jpg":null,"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/barracuda-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn73@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-11-195_c7cac540e252881d.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Daredevil-Punisher-chains-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn66@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-09-464_740fdaf701aa0c84.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/nicky-cavella-slain-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn97@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-35-09-751_9078561b275ba905.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/war-machine-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn54@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-05-946_f222b7a14c774a8c.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/k-frost-giant-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn5@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-35-10-615_ab13f4f1aaffc80e.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/the-end-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn98@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-14-782_82ad31c7603dac22.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/man-of-stone-Cropped.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700505},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"DCeased: DC's Greatest Detective Reveals How to Destroy Humanity","link":"https://www.cbr.com/dceased-detective-chimp-destroy-humanity/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-Constantine-DCeased.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for </strong></em><strong><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/dceased/\">DCeased: Hope at World's End</a> </strong><em><strong>#8, by Tom Taylor, Karl Mostert, Trevor Scott, Rex Lokus and Saida Temofonte, on sale now.</strong></em></p><p>In the DC Universe, Detective Chimp has often touted that no matter how much Batman gets the credit for being the greatest detective in history, he's <em>really </em>the best detective in the DC Universe He respects Batman, but he believes in himself even more, as we've seen in the recent<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/justice-league-dark/\"><em> Justice League Dark</em></a> stories.</p><p>And come <em>DCeased: Hope at World's End</em> #8, Bobo lives up to his word as he actually reveals that he knows precisely how to destroy all humanity. The shocking thing is it's way simpler than anything the Batman could have come up with if he broke bad.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dceased-shadowpact-revival/\">DCeased Revives a DOOMED Fan-Favorite DC Team</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/detective-chimp.jpg\"/></figure><p>When Batman breaks bad, his plans usually revolve around impossibly complex schemes to systematically take out his opponents. The Dark Knight wades into the problem on a granular level and determines the best course of action, using clues and evidence provided, but Bobo is all about simplicity and the minuscule things we often overlook.</p><p>As he traverses the Earth with the Blighted Ones overrunning it, Detective Chimp rescues a young girl, Amy, and works with Ace the Bat-Hound to get her to Poison Ivy's garden. Bobo is immune, since the Anti-Life virus only infects people, as he says its progenitors were too arrogant, thinking animals weren't important enough to wipe out. They don't consider animals to be sentient but Bobo proves otherwise by speaking to them as if he's Dr. Doolittle. It's then and there, he tells Amy if the villains were smart, however, they'd just put the virus in <em>mosquitoes</em>.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dceased-hawkman-death/\">DCeased Reveals How a MAJOR Justice League Hero Died</a></span></p><p>As Bobo alludes to, it's brilliant because people wouldn't suspect that the bites from the pests are anything but normal. it's just accepted we get bit by them. The most we might do is call vector control but in the DCU, if mosquitoes were spreading this disease, people would be quicker to look to villains like the Joker or Lex Luthor. Bobo's point is that mosquitoes are taken for granted as they can cover so much ground and exist almost anywhere. They don't need specific conditions, so they can transmit a virus in places as diverse as murky lagoons, cold office spaces, dark alleys or superhero secret hideouts.</p><p>While Bob is making a cheeky statement here, it's also an indictment on why animals should be taken seriously, especially mosquitoes. Still, Detective Chimp has seemingly given humanity's potential annihilation a disturbing amount of thought.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dceased-unites-detective-chimp-ace-krypto/\">DCeased Unites the World's Finest Sidekicks</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 22:20:27 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-Constantine-DCeased.jpg","linkMd5":"6bebe90da1cef41b609317af7f7ae391","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn30@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-02-438_e36c7a444ec4b7b4.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":199344,"destBytes":199344,"author":"Renaldo Matadeen","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-Constantine-DCeased.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn30@2020_5/2020/09/01/02-35-02-438_e36c7a444ec4b7b4.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/detective-chimp.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn39@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-17-094_c5ab7962110cc829.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700504},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"Daredevil Just Put Matt Murdock on a Crash Course With ANOTHER Kingpin","link":"https://www.cbr.com/daredevil-matt-murdock-hood-crash-course/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Daredevil-Costume-feature.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for </strong></em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/daredevil/\"><strong>Daredevil Annual</strong></a><em><strong> #1 by Chip Zdarsky, Manuel Garcia, Le Beau Underwood, Chris Mooneyham, Rachelle Rosenberg and VC's Clayton Cowles, available now.</strong></em></p><p>Daredevil's life has been going through a series of major changes recently, most notably with the hero facing a trial for his accidental killing of a criminal. But the biggest change might be the way reality was just shifted around <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/daredevil-annual-mike-murdock-history/\">his \"brother\" Mike Murdock,</a> who has gone from an assumed identity to a living, breathing being.</p><p>In <em>Daredevil Annual </em>#1, Mike Murdock just ensured he has a true life in the Marvel Universe, but he did so at the cost of setting the criminal kingpin known as the Hood after him, setting up Daredevil to go into battle with the villain.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/daredevil-matt-murdock-spider-man-showdown/\">Marvel Teases Spider-Man's Showdown With... Daredevil?!</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Daredevil-Mike-Murdock-Hood.jpg\"/></figure><p>Michael Murdock began life as a secondary identity developed by Matt Murdock, aka Daredevil. Mike proved to be a useful tool for Daredevil over the years, with Matt using the alias to go undercover as a crook more than once. However, while working with the Inhuman Reader to try and bring down Wilson Fisk, Mike was accidentally manifested in the real world by Reader's abilities. Matt initially intended for Reader to erase this fragment, but Matt eventually decided that he wanted to give Mike the chance to live. Mike quickly ended up separated from his brother and began working for the Hood, at the recommendation of Wilson Fisk, the former Kingpin and current Mayor of New York.</p><p>Formerly a member of Norman Osborn's Cabal and the kingpin of his own superpowered gang, the Hood has been quietly reasserting his power in the New York criminal underworld, partly by recovering the Asgardian Nord Stones that previously empowered him. Using their time together as a means to get close to Hood, the two quickly seem to become friends. But it's all a trick, leading to Mike finding out where the Hood hides the Nord Stone and even the combination to the safe. Mike is able to get ahold of books detailing the use of objects like the Nord Stone, allowing Mike to access the reality-bending attributes of the Asgardian artifact and ensure his existence.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/daredevil-matt-murdock-suits-up/\">Daredevil: Why Matt Murdock Officially Suits Up Again</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/The-Hood-1.jpg\"/></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/daredevil-annual-mike-murdock-history/\">This changes reality</a> so that Mike always actually existed as a living, breathing brother to Matt Murdock. But it also doesn't change the fact that Mike worked with the Hood and openly betrayed him. When Daredevil approaches him later, he reveals that the Hood is looking for Mike and is on the warpath, seeking revenge for his theft. Daredevil's own personal issues with his upcoming manslaughter trial will keep him from being able to fully protect his brother, but it's unlikely that a good man like Daredevil will be able to turn his back on his newly established brother.</p><p>This means Matt might soon fight himself dealing with a former Avengers-level threat in pursuit of saving a brother who intends to help take over the criminal side of New York City. While Mike has his new ally Butch -- who's apparently the son of Wilson Fisk -- there's a chance that Mike still also has access to the Nord Stone. Although the artifact appears exhausted of any energy after he affects reality, it's still a potentially valuable tool. While it wouldn't be surprising if the reality-bending effects of his choice drained it of power, it would just make the Hood even more furious with his former partner. The beginnings of a new gang war in New York might be brewing, and Mike's choices put Daredevil directly into the sights of the Hood.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/empyre-wolverine-spider-man-marvel-event/\">Empyre: How Wolverine &#38; Spider-Man Get Drafted Into The Marvel Event</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 21:20:36 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Daredevil-Costume-feature.jpg","linkMd5":"7bf973f922a78df062b2a8651fe60705","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn18@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-00-719_69c62ab61be41252.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":113622,"destBytes":113622,"author":"Brandon Zachary","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Daredevil-Costume-feature.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn18@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-35-00-719_69c62ab61be41252.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Daredevil-Mike-Murdock-Hood.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn14@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-35-12-321_f4caeebd640ceb23.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/The-Hood-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn13@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-07-230_389ac314039e5699.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700505},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"The Green Lantern: Liam Sharp Says Series Is Grant Morrison's Last DC Work, Ever","link":"https://www.cbr.com/green-lantern-grant-morrison-last-dc-work-ever/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Green-Lantern-Corps-Liam-Sharp.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-green-lantern/\">The Green Lantern</a></em> artist Liam Sharp revealed the series' Season 2 conclusion will also be a wrap for writer <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/grant-morrison/\">Grant Morrison's</a> career with DC.</p><p>Sharp responded to a fan asking about a possible Season 3, tweeting, \"It was always planned as two seasons of twelve issues each, so that’ll be it. Grant says it’s his last ever DC work. I still have four issues to draw mind, so I’m not done quite yet! :-)\"</p><iframe width=\"320\" height=\"320\" frameborder=\"0\" src=\"https://twitter.com/liamrsharp/status/1298076848434188288\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe><iframe width=\"320\" height=\"320\" frameborder=\"0\" src=\"https://twitter.com/LiamRSharp/status/1298508904867930112\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/green-lantern-hal-jordan-dies-again/\">Green Lantern: One of DC's Greatest Heroes Just Died - Again</a></span></p><p>A couple of days later, Sharp added, \"This time I think it’s true. He doesn’t need the work, and most of his associates have gone now. Time to concentrate on his own material I think! :-)\"</p><p>Morrison has written a number of titles for DC, including <em>Batman and Robin</em>, <em>All-Star Superman, The Multiversity</em> and <em>The Invisibles</em>, <em>Animal Man</em> and <em>Doom Patrol</em> for Vertigo, as well as writing creator-owned works.</p><p>Prior to joining Morrison on <em>The Green Lantern</em>, Sharp served as the artist on <em>Wonder Woman</em> and as the writer/artist on <em>The Brave and the Bold</em>.</p><p><em>The Green Lantern: Season 2</em> #6, by Grant Morrison, Liam Sharp, Steve Oliff and Steve Wands, is on sale now from DC.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/grant-morrison-silver-age-favorite-comics-era/\">Grant Morrison Explains Why the Silver Age Is His Favorite Comics Era</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 19:51:04 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Green-Lantern-Corps-Liam-Sharp.jpg","linkMd5":"7fd923301de2421311fdbdec881098cc","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn50@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-02-858_6246069e567c2c3c.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":280508,"destBytes":238482,"author":"Kelvin Childs","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Green-Lantern-Corps-Liam-Sharp.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn50@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-35-02-858_6246069e567c2c3c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598927700507},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:35:00","title":"When Gotham Is Ashes: 10 Best Bane Fanart | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/dc-batman-bane-fan-art/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bane-fan-art-banner.jpg\"/></figure><p>Few can break <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/batman\">Batman</a> like <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/bane/\">Bane</a>. Introduced in <em>Batman: Vengeance of Bane</em> #1, the character quickly gained notoriety by fracturing the Dark Knight’s spine. His moral compass fluctuates but often points toward evil. Recently, the character dealt Batman another crushing blow by murdering the Caped Crusader's butler and father figure, Alfred Pennyworth.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-batman-bane-most-villanious-acts/\">Batman: The 10 Worst Things Bane Has Ever Done, Ranked</a></span></p><p>A master strategist who often uses the strength-enhancing drug Venom, Bane has become extremely popular, with <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-dark-knight-rises/\">The Dark Knight Rises</a></em> boosting his profile further. Just as Bane tried to rouse disenfranchised Gothamites in the film, he has also inspired fan artists to draw his likeness…proving that even when the fire dims, the pencil rises.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>“Bane Vs Venom 3: Tom vs Tom” By Andy P. Timm</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bane-vs-Venom-fan-art-by-Andy-W.-Timm.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/ptimm/art/Bane-vs-Venom-3-Tom-vs-Tom-791750550\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Original image</a> from <a href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/ptimm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Timm’s DeviantArt page</a>.</p><p>It’s not just Tom vs. Tom, but Venom vs. Venom, as Bane squares off in an arm-wrestling match <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/venom-eddie-brock-dc-superheroes-fight/\">against Eddie Brock</a> and symbiote while Marvel and DC Universe spectators watch. The characters have a lot in common at this point, as they both rely on something called “Venom” to amplify their strength and have been played by Tom Hardy in film.</p><p>Bane also is somewhat of a dark mirror to Batman, albeit not as overtly as Venom is to <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spider-man/\">Spider-Man</a>. Like the Dark Knight, Bane is <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/10-batman-villains-you-wouldnt-think-are-smarter-than-the-joker-but-actually-are/\">extremely calculating</a> and gifted in combat, even without his trademark drug.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>“Bane” By Jose Real</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bane-fan-art-by-Jose-Real.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/joserealart/art/Bane-742750186\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Original image</a> from <a href=\"https://www.deviantart.com/joserealart/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Real's DeviantArt page</a>.</p><p>Real draws a redesigned Bane with visible eyes (rather than obscured by red coverings) and a greatly expanded Venom delivery system. Rather than simply connected between his arm and head, the tubes that carry the drug through Bane’s body cover both straps of his luchador-inspired jumpsuit and is one of the only parts of the piece that’s in color.</p><p>The other elements in green, of course, are Bane’s eyes, which reveal that Venom is most definitely flowing into him. His bulging veins and muscles, of course, are also big giveaways.
